the qustion: Hypertension is defined as SBP ≥140 mm Hg or DBP ≥90 mm Hg on three separate occasions.
explanation: JNC 7 defines HTN as SBP ≥140 or DBP ≥90 on three readings.

the qustion: The 2017 ACC/AHA guidelines define hypertension as SBP ≥130 mm Hg or DBP ≥80 mm Hg.
For every 20 mm Hg systolic or 10 mm Hg diastolic increase, cardiovascular risk doubles.
explanation: Risk of major CV events doubles per 20/10 mm Hg rise.

the qustion: Hypertension affects over 1.2 billion people worldwide.
More than 50% of hypertensive patients are undertreated.
explanation: Over half remain undertreated with poor control.

the qustion: Isolated systolic hypertension is SBP ≥140 mm Hg with DBP <90 mm Hg.
Isolated diastolic hypertension is SBP <140 mm Hg with DBP ≥90 mm Hg.
Hypertensive urgency is BP >180/120 mm Hg with end-organ damage.
explanation: Urgency has no acute organ damage.

the qustion: Hypertensive emergency is BP >180/120 mm Hg with evidence of end-organ damage.
Primary (essential) hypertension accounts for ~90% of cases.
explanation: Essential HTN makes up 90% of cases.

the qustion: Secondary hypertension is responsible for 5–10% of cases.
Lifestyle factors such as obesity and high sodium intake promote essential HTN.
explanation: Obesity, inactivity, alcohol, sodium promote HTN.

the qustion: Pheochromocytoma is a common cause of secondary hypertension.
Obstructive sleep apnea is not a reversible cause of secondary HTN.
explanation: OSA is a reversible secondary cause.

the qustion: Hypertension in patients <30 years old suggests secondary causes.
Family history of premature CVD (<55 years) suggests secondary HTN evaluation.
explanation: Premature CVD raises suspicion for secondary HTN.

the qustion: Routine initial HTN evaluation includes TSH testing.
explanation: TSH is part of standard labs.

the qustion: 24-hour urine cortisol is mandatory for all HTN patients.
Home BP ≥135/85 mm Hg confirms hypertension.
ABPM daytime average >135/85 mm Hg and nighttime >125/75 mm Hg diagnoses HTN.
explanation: ABPM thresholds differ day vs night.

the qustion: Masked hypertension carries similar CVD risk as sustained HTN.
White-coat hypertension has no increased cardiovascular risk.
Lifestyle modification is first-line therapy for stage 1 hypertension.
The DASH diet emphasizes fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and low-fat dairy.
explanation: DASH is rich in produce and low-fat dairy.

the qustion: DASH diet sodium intake should be <1500 mg/day.
Potassium supplements are routinely recommended to treat HTN.
explanation: Evidence is insufficient; focus on diet.

the qustion: Weight loss of 10 kg lowers SBP by 5–20 mm Hg.
explanation: 10 kg loss yields substantial BP drop.

the qustion: Moderate-vigorous activity 3–4×/week for 40 min/session lowers BP by 4–9 mm Hg.
Garlic supplements are proven effective for HTN control.
explanation: Current evidence does not support routine use.

the qustion: Alcohol reduction to ≤2 drinks/day lowers SBP by 2–4 mm Hg.
explanation: Moderating alcohol yields modest BP drop.

the qustion: Pharmacologic therapy in patients ≥60 starts at SBP ≥150 or DBP ≥90 mm Hg.
For patients <60, treatment begins at SBP ≥140 or DBP ≥90 mm Hg.
ACE inhibitors are first-line for essential hypertension.
Beta-blockers are preferred initial therapy for hypertension.
explanation: BBs are not first-line without other indications.

the qustion: Thiazide diuretics are recommended first-line in African-Americans without CKD.
explanation: JNC 8 advises thiazides or CCBs for African-Americans.

the qustion: ACE inhibitors are contraindicated during pregnancy.
ACE inhibitors often cause a persistent dry cough.
ARBs cause cough at the same rate as ACE inhibitors.
explanation: ARBs have lower rates of cough.

the qustion: Calcium channel blockers are classified as dihydropyridines and non-dihydropyridines.
Peripheral edema is a common side effect of dihydropyridine CCBs.
explanation: Dihydropyridines cause arteriolar dilation and edema.

the qustion: Thiazide diuretics can cause hypokalemia, hyperuricemia, and hyperglycemia.
explanation: They have multiple metabolic side effects.

the qustion: Loop diuretics are preferred in GFR <30 mL/min patients.
explanation: Loops remain effective at low GFR.

the qustion: Spironolactone is indicated for resistant HTN even without hyperaldosteronism.
Initial combination therapy is recommended when BP >160/100 mm Hg.
At least one antihypertensive (not diuretic) should be dosed at bedtime if on two drugs.
explanation: Night dosing improves nocturnal BP control.

the qustion: Beta-blockers are contraindicated in asthma and COPD.
Metoprolol succinate 25 mg daily is a typical starting dose.
explanation: Metoprolol succinate starts at 12.5–25 mg daily.

the qustion: Resistant HTN is defined as BP above goal on ≥3 optimally dosed meds including a diuretic.
Hypertensive emergencies most commonly present with acute pulmonary edema and cerebral infarction.
explanation: These are the most frequent emergencies.

the qustion: Hypertensive urgency is managed with rapid IV therapy.
explanation: Urgency is managed with oral meds over hours.

the qustion: In emergencies, reduce BP by no more than 25% in the first hour.
explanation: Avoid rapid drops to prevent ischemia.

the qustion: Elderly patients often have isolated systolic hypertension.
In elderly with CKD, ACE inhibitors are preferred unless contraindicated.
African-American patients respond better to ACE inhibitors than thiazides.
In pregnancy, methyldopa and labetalol are safe first-line agents.
Hydralazine is contraindicated in pregnancy due to fluid retention.
explanation: Hydralazine can be used despite tachycardia side effects.

the qustion: Refer resistant HTN patients if BP uncontrolled after 6 months.
explanation: Specialist referral is advised after 6 months.

the qustion: Refer any patient with suspected secondary HTN.
Risk factors for essential HTN include age, family history, obesity, and stress.
Which staging system uses SBP 120–139 and/or DBP 80–89 mm Hg as elevated BP?
JNC 7 Prehypertension is defined as SBP 120–139 and/or DBP 80–89 mm Hg.
In JNC 7, Grade II HTN is SBP 160–179 and/or DBP 100–109 mm Hg.
A 24-hour ABPM daytime average >135/85 mm Hg confirms HTN.
HBPM requires measurements morning and evening for 7 days, discarding day 1.
Rapid‐acting oral captopril is used in hypertensive urgency.
explanation: Oral captopril is indicated in urgency.

the qustion: ABPM readings are taken every 15–30 min while awake and 30–60 min during sleep.
Fundoscopy in HTN emergency may show papilledema and cotton‐wool spots.
explanation: Retinal findings reflect acute organ damage.

the qustion: Carotid bruits are evaluated during HTN clinical examination.
Renal artery stenosis should be screened in all HTN patients.
explanation: Screen only if suspected by clinical clues.

the qustion: Left ventricular hypertrophy on ECG is a complication of chronic HTN.
Hyaline arteriolosclerosis is a microvascular change in HTN.
explanation: Affects small vessels in chronic HTN.

the qustion: Subarachnoid hemorrhage is a possible hypertensive emergency outcome.
Chronic HTN does not affect kidney function.
Stroke symptoms include unilateral weakness and aphasia.
Hypertensive encephalopathy features headache, confusion, and seizures.
ACE inhibitors reduce mortality in post-MI hypertensive patients.
ACE inhibitors are contraindicated in bilateral renal artery stenosis.
explanation: ACEIs worsen renal function in bilateral RAS.

the qustion: NSAIDs can worsen blood pressure control.
Thiazide diuretics can exacerbate gout by raising uric acid.
Beta-blockers are ideal for first-line HTN without other indications.
explanation: BBs not preferred initial therapy absent compelling indication.

the qustion: Combination therapy with ACEI + CCB is Grade 1B recommended.
explanation: ACEI/ARB + dihydropyridine CCB is preferred combo.

the qustion: Combination therapy with ACEI + thiazide is Grade 1B recommended.
Resistant HTN management may include spironolactone if K+ <5 mEq/L.
explanation: Spironolactone helps resistant HTN with safe K+.

the qustion: Renal ultrasound is part of routine HTN evaluation.
explanation: Renal imaging is optional with suspicion.
